node.text:
Melissa is a mommy of two and a speech-language pathologist specializing in babies and toddlers. Melissa's passion is teaching parents how to talk to their little ones in a way that gets them talking back! She has helped thousands of parents get their young children talking through her Raising Little Talkers online course, her beloved Instagram page of the same name, and her private practice in Los Angeles. 

Follow her at @raisinglittletalkers for more advice and information.

In this episode, Melissa answers:

1. My child is 18 months old and says at least 50 words, but doesn’t say mama. What do I do? 

2. What is the best tip for helping a 1-year-old to imitate speech and gestures? 

3. Will speaking two languages to my baby slow down their learning to speak? 

4. My 12-month-old regressed from saying “mama” to no words for 2 months. When to worry? 

5. Is it bad to use nicknames for items like “susu” for soother? 

6. Does sign language help or hinder speech and language development? 

7. What’s an appropriate age for a speech and language evaluation?

#speech #language #SLP #childdevelopment #expertadvice

node.title: Speech and Language Development: Melissa Minney, Part 1

node.text:
Jenny Best is the founder of Solid Starts (@solidstarts), a team of pediatric food + feeding experts, doctors, nutritionists, and dietitians, and the world’s first comprehensive platform for starting babies on solid food. Solid Starts features the First Foods®️ database, a free food database and app complete with instructions and how-to videos for introducing real food to babies. Solid Starts serves more than one million people from 175 countries worldwide, offering complimentary resources to those facing economic hardship. 

Follow @solidstarts for more advice and information.

In this episode, Jenny answers:

1. What is baby-led weaning (BLW)?

2. How does choking happen?

3. What are the best foods to start with?

4. How can I do baby-led weaning with food allergies?

#solidstarts #feeding #babyledweaning #blw #babydevelopment #expertadvice

node.text:
Veronica Fernandez, PhD, is a developmental psychologist and research scientist at the University of Miami. Her research focuses on understanding and improving the quality of interactions and early learning experiences for children. 

She uses inquiry and play as mechanisms to promote equity for cultural and linguistically diverse children, families, and teachers. Most importantly, she is the mommy of a curious and spunky bilingual toddler — so she is putting her research into practice every day.

Follow her at @cultivating.wonder_ for more advice and information.

In this episode, Veronica answers:

1. Is it okay to introduce a second language when neither parent is bilingual? Is it appropriative?

2. What’s the number one recommendation for encouraging a bilingual home (if you had to pick just one)?

#bilingual #multilingual #earlylearning #language #expertadvice

node.text:
Veronica Fernandez, PhD, is a developmental psychologist and research scientist at the University of Miami. Her research focuses on understanding and improving the quality of interactions and early learning experiences for children. 

She uses inquiry and play as mechanisms to promote equity for cultural and linguistically diverse children, families, and teachers. Most importantly, she is the mommy of a curious and spunky bilingual toddler — so she is putting her research into practice every day.

Follow her at @cultivating.wonder_ for more advice and information.

In this episode, Veronica answers:

1. Do I have to be fluent in a language to teach my child?

2. What if only one parent is bilingual?

3. It’s hard to have one-sided conversations in a language.

4. Will learning another language delay my child’s speech?

5. Will speaking 2 or 3 languages confuse or overwhelm my child?

#bilingual #multilingual #earlylearning #language #expertadvice

node.text:
Elina Furman is a Certified Infant Massage Instructor with over 15 years in the baby product industry. She is deeply passionate about spreading awareness about the importance of infant/child massage. She earned her certification after talking to many parents who were confused and bewildered about how to perform infant massage. 

By creating an educational platform and a massage enhancement tool, Elina hopes to bridge the gap of knowledge to help parents and underserved families explore this science evidence-based practice performed for thousands of years all over the world.
Follow her at @getkahlmi for more information and tips. 

In this IGTV, Elina answers:

1. What are the benefits of infant massage?

2. How to start and when to do it? How often? And until what age?

3. What if it seems like my baby doesn’t like massage?

4. Does infant massage help babies sleep better?

5. How do we continue with massage for older children?

6. Can massages relieve gas discomfort and can it be done before my baby gets to that point?

7. Are there any massages to help with teething?

#infantmassage #babydevelopment #expertadvice

node.text:
Gopika Kamdar, MA, CCC-SLP is a Licensed Speech-Language Pathologist with a passion for the human brain, early childhood development, and parent coaching.

Her work focuses on how all parts of development play an integral part of speech and language development. Follow her at @speechwithgopika for more advice and information.

In this episode, Gopika answers:

1. What age to worry about common mispronounced letters? (ex. R as W) Should my baby get evaluated professionally? 

2. How can I encourage my 3 year old to expand his short sentences?

3. Will mask-wearing by teachers affect the speech development of my 4 month old at daycare?

4. Does using a pacifier until at least 6 months of age affect speech?

Be sure to watch all 3 IGTV videos in this series to hear all of Gopika's answers to the top questions on speech and language development. ✨

node.text:
Gopika Kamdar, MA, CCC-SLP is a Licensed Speech-Language Pathologist with a passion for the human brain, early childhood development, and parent coaching.

Her work focuses on how all parts of development play an integral part of speech and language development. Follow her at @speechwithgopika for more advice and information.

In this episode, Gopika answers:

1. Should I be concerned about my two year old having a lisp? What causes them? 
2. When should I be worried about other people not understanding my 2 year old? 
3. When should babies start babbling? Is it concerning if an 8 month old baby doesn’t babble? Tips to encourage babbling?

Be sure to watch all 3 IGTV videos in this series to hear all of Gopika's answers to the top questions on speech and language development. ✨

#slp #speech #language #childdevelopment #expertadvice

node.title: Speech and Language Development: Gopika Kamdar, Part 2

Gopika Kamdar, MA, CCC-SLP is a Licensed Speech-Language Pathologist with a passion for the human brain, early childhood development, and parent coaching.

Her work focuses on how all parts of development play an integral part of speech and language development. Follow her at @speechwithgopika for more advice and information.

In this episode, Gopika answers:

1. How will speech develop for children in a bilingual family? Will it cause a delay in their speech?

2. Tips to help a 3 year old with stuttering? Should I see a doctor right away?

Be sure to watch all 3 IGTV videos in this series to hear all of Gopika's answers to the top questions on speech and language development. ✨

#slp #speech #language #childdevelopment #expertadvice

node.text:
Lauren Heffernan is a three-time Certified Pediatric Sleep Specialist with a focus on attachment. She is the owner of Isla-Grace Sleep (@islagracesleep) and the co-creator of the Baby-Led Sleep Approach.

Lauren is passionate about helping families to get more sleep without the use of any sleep training. Follow her at @islagracesleep for more advice and information.

In this episode, Lauren answers:

1. My toddler refuses to sleep in his bed and comes to our bed every night. How do I get him to sleep in his own bed after co-sleeping since birth?

2. What do you think about bedsharing?

Be sure to watch all five ✋ IGTV videos in this series to hear all of Lauren's answers to the top questions on sleep. ✨

#sleep #babysleep #toddlersleep #expertadvice #sleepconsultant #attachmentparenting

node.text:
Lauren Heffernan is a three-time Certified Pediatric Sleep Specialist with a focus on attachment. She is the owner of Isla-Grace Sleep (@islagracesleep) and the co-creator of the Baby-Led Sleep Approach.

Lauren is passionate about helping families to get more sleep without the use of any sleep training. Follow her at @islagracesleep for more advice and information.

In this episode, Lauren answers:

1. Tips for transitioning to one nap?

2. Is co-sleeping with a 2-year-old okay? When should this end?

Be sure to watch all five ✋ IGTV videos in this series to hear all of Lauren's answers to the top questions on sleep. ✨

#sleep #babysleep #toddlersleep #expertadvice #sleepconsultant #attachmentparenting

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Lovevery on July 31, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'Tip: are Babies love sensory play, but it can certainly get messy. Sensory bags a great compromise: they allow your baby to explore without the mess. LOVEVERY'.

node.text:
As your baby squishes and squashes a sensory bag and moves the contents around, your baby absorbs new information about the world through their fingers, eyes, and ears—maybe even their mouth. This is perfectly okay, but do be sure to closely supervise your baby when they’re playing with a sensory bag! 👍

You can introduce sensory bags when your baby is about 6 months old and can reach and use their hands. It’s a fun activity to continue throughout their first year. 

Fill a resealable plastic bag with tactile materials like hair gel, pumpkin seeds, shaving cream, or marbles. Reinforce the seal with strong tape, then use painter’s or washi tape to secure the edges of the bag to the floor or a table where your baby can play. 🙌 

Here are some fun sensory bag ideas: 👇

✨ Food coloring + water + oil 

✨ Frozen Peas + water

✨ Shaving cream + food coloring 

✨ Pumpkin seeds 

✨ Pom poms + hair gel 

✨ Buttons + hair gel 

✨ Sponges + food coloring + water 

✨ Ice 

Be sure to remove as much air as possible from the bag -- it works best this way. 

Happy (supervised) playing! ❤️

#sensoryplay #sensoryactivities #sensoryactivity #sensorybags #babyactivities #babydevelopment #learnthroughplay #playtolearn #learningactivities #lovevery

node.text:
Toddlers LOVE to practice buckling! It might seem like a random activity for your little one to love, but these tiny humans get obsessed. Learning how to use buckles, buttons, snaps, and zippers is a challenge requiring advanced fine motor skills. ⁣👊⁣
⁣⁣
The Buckle Barrel promotes a lot of benefits for your toddler, including bilateral coordination (using both hands together), hand-eye coordination, finger dexterity, and their pincer grasp👌. It’s also the perfect activity for on the go!⁣ 🚗✈️⁣
⁣⁣
Start by unbuckling all of the buckles and showing your toddler how they fit back together. Encourage them to buckle the buckles by themselves.
⁣
Give them time to explore this toy independently. 👍 As their fingers and fine motor strength develop, they’ll be able to unbuckle the buckles on their own. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Some of the buckles are easier than others and many kids over the age of 2 will still be figuring it out. 🤔 This definitely takes time ⏰ and a lot of practice, but your toddler will be a pro buckler soon enough.⁣ ⁣

Thanks to @jetset.away for tagging us in this video. 💕

#toddleractivities #toddlerdevelopment #bilateralcoordination #pincergrasp #toddlerlife #toddlers #toddlerlearning #learningthroughplay #playtolearn #sustainabletoys #lovevery

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Lovevery on July 29, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says '8 strategies to help your toddler (and yourself) move on from a tantrum. LOVEVERY.'.

node.text:
It’s a universally acknowledged fact that toddlers are emotional. The volume and intensity of their emotion, however, can still take anyone by surprise. 🙃

Your toddler can’t rely the way adults do on experience; they’re learning as they go. Let’s say you give your child two pieces of broken cracker and they dissolve into tears. You know that a broken cracker will taste the same as a whole one, but they don’t. 

More often than not, the root cause of a tantrum is your child wanting independence but not being quite ready for it. The constant push-and-pull between wanting to do things on their own but not having the tools for it—combined with a brain that’s still developing—can cause big emotions, unpredictable mood swings, and major frustration.

Click the link in our bio for more information on how you can implement these 8 strategies to help your toddler--and yourself--move on from a tantrum. ❤️

#tantrum #tantrumtips #toddlers #toddlertips #lovevery

node.text:
Teamwork makes the dream work! 🌟

The Montessori Math Bars & Number Tiles from the Problem Solver Play Kit (43-45 months) are a great way to help your three-year-old build math fundamentals visually with concrete objects to count, line up, and compare. 🔢

The Number Sense Nature Counters can be played on their own for counting activities or imaginative play. They can also be used with the Wooden Unit Bars and Number Tiles for more concrete counting exercise. 

The ways to play are endless. You can combine early math and counting skills, practice color matching, work on language development, strengthen fine motor skills, and the list goes on! 👏

This activity can also be used to practice sharing and turn-taking, as shown in this video from @laurenhadalittlelamb of her daughters Ella and Rose playing together. 💘

#mathactivities #toddlermath #toddlercounting #math #teachingmath #learningmath #toddlermath #learningnumbers #toddlerdevelopment #toddlerlearning #toddlerlife #woodentoys #sustainabletoys #learningthroughplay #playtolearn #lovevery

node.text:
This easy activity has many developmental benefits and is great for a food-motivated baby! 😉

Place a puff or other small snack your child is familiar with inside a container from the Little Grip Canister Set (which is from the Explorer Play Kit for 9-10 months). Encourage your child to open the container all on their own. 🙌

This activity will work their fine motor skills and pincer grasp, while teaching them about patience, problem solving, and containment (the idea that items inside containers will stay inside them until opened)!

Thanks for sharing this video with us, @laciethornton. If you try this puff play with your baby, make sure to tag us. 🤩

Please be sure to supervise your baby during this activity and put materials safely away when play is done.

#babydevelopment #physicaldevelopment #braindevelopment #babyactivities #babylearning #learningthroughplay #playtolearn #lovevery

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Lovevery on July 25, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'Fact: Babies begin to recognize ther names as early as six months old. LOVEVERY'.

node.text:
The first time you say your baby’s name and they turn to look at you because they recognize their name is one of the sweetest moments in the world—and it can start to happen when your baby is about 6 months old. 🤩

You may have seen your baby turn to you when you said their name before, even when they were only a few weeks old. This was because they recognized the sound of your voice. (In fact, they have known your unique voice since before they were born.) ✨

Research indicates that a baby doesn’t truly understand their “ownership” of their name until they are around 6 months old. Repeating your baby’s name makes it easier for them to learn it, especially when you speak in affectionate tones and with emphasis. 💕

In addition to recognizing their own name, your baby may be starting to make correlations between familiar combinations of sounds and the objects or people they denote. For example if you say the word “ball” and point at a ball, your baby may realize the connection, though they won’t be able to say the word until they are 10 to 12 months old.

Can you remember the moment you realized your baby knew their name? Share with us in the comments. ❤️

#lovevery #babydevelopment #loveverybaby #firstwords #namerecognition

node.text:
This balloon kicking activity is one of our favorites! It’s a great way to strengthen gross motor skills. It also strengthens eye muscles to improve tracking and helps develop concentration. 👌⁣⁠

Around 5 months, your little one is figuring out that their legs and feet are a part of them! 👣 ⁠
⁠
When they kick, they start to understand that their body can create noise or movement… a fun way to understand cause and effect! 🙌⁣⁠
⁠
They are also building important neck strength by tucking their chin to look down at their legs and feet. This “chin tuck” helps build important muscles needed for rolling over from back to side, and then eventually from their back to belly.⁣⁠ 💪 ⁠
⁠⁠
Tie a couple of helium balloons loosely around your little one’s ankles and let them get comfortable. You can encourage them to start kicking by moving their legs for them and showing them how the balloons move.⁣⁠ 🎈⁠

Thanks for tagging us in this adorable video with us @_mommy.g_ (we also spy one of our Organic Cotton Quilts👀)! 💕

Please be sure to supervise your baby during this activity and put materials safely away when play is done.

#babyactivities #babyactivity #grossmotorskills #athomeactivities #lovevery

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Lovevery on July 23, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'Fact: Research suggests limiting screen time for toddlers, but screens can be valuable for connecting. LOVEVERY RY'.

node.text:
A study led by Dr. Jenny Radesky found parents pick up their phones almost 70 times a day, so it makes sense that young children are intrigued by screens. We aren't trying to parent-shame anyone for using screen time, we've all been there before and will be again.

For general purposes, the American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) recommends short viewings of high-quality programming (think PBS or Sesame Street) for 18 to 24-month-olds. 📺

Screen use for children ages 2-5 years should be limited to one hour of the same kind of high-quality programming alongside parents to help children understand what they’re watching. 👍

The AAP’s recommendation is no screens for babies younger than 18 months, except when video chatting with family.

According to the AAP, video chatting is a valuable use of screen time for all children. Social and cognitive information become entwined in real-time conversations like these—even online.

Non-screen activities may be a little bit harder for your child to get into at first. Sit down and build a block tower with them, or try reading a book together and using blocks or play-dough to make something they saw in the story. 👏

Here are some alternatives to screen time: 

🌟 “By yourself” bins
The toys in a “by yourself” bin make rare appearances, so they feel more special and can keep your toddler’s attention a little longer. You can rotate the contents of a single bin or make several with different themes, like vehicles, objects from nature, art supplies, and cooking utensils (the bins can hold more than just toys 🙂)

🌟 Collection of collections
Building a collection of favorite things, like dinosaurs, cars, or rocks, may help capture your child’s imagination, especially if they add to it regularly. Your child creates the collection, has control over it, and—best of all—is expert in it.

🌟 Construction zone
Supply your construction zone with objects of varying sizes, shapes, and materials. You can start with traditional building toys such as blocks, legos, and magnetic tiles, and inspire your child to take their structures to the next level with found objects like fabric scraps, rocks, shells, sticks, and wood.

#screentime #lovevery

The perfect color-mixing activity for your toddler - and it only requires food coloring! 🙌🌈

@alexxmiles used the Liquid Lab from the The Investigator Play Kit for months 31-33 to swirl blue and red food coloring for her little one, Tatum, to combine. Tatum is so excited to see the red and blue mix together to make purple. 🤩

Keep tagging us in these adorable videos, we love seeing what experiments you and your little scientists come up with using the Liquid Lab! 🧪

#stemlearning #stem #stemfortoddlers #toddlerdevelopment #learningthroughplay #playtolearn #lovevery

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Lovevery on July 21, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'What's something your toddler has said to you that you'll never forget? #LoveveryRealTalk'.

node.text:
Our toddlers say some unforgettable things. 💕 

Here’s a few from our team: 

❤️: “In response to me, when I seem frustrated, ‘but Mom, I’m still little and I’m learning.’”

😂: "Sometimes I really want to be a big person (read: an adult) because you can do whatever you want. But I don't want to work."

🙃: “In response to Mother's Day and Father's Day.... ‘When is it going to be kid's day?!’”

🥰: “Thanks for being my superhero, Mama.”

From the funny phrases that make us laugh out loud, to the sweet ways they say “I love you,” what is something your toddler has said to you that you’ll never forget? 👇

#funnytoddler #cutetoddler #thingstoddlerssay #toddlerlife #toddlerdevelopment #toddlers #loveveryrealtalk #lovevery

Parents are generally unaware of how ready young toddlers are to learn about numbers. We hear plenty about how important reading is for young children, but early introductions to math matter just as much. 👍

Neuroscientist, Gillian Starkey, says introducing your toddler to math can happen in the course of your regular day; it doesn’t have to require anything special. There are lots of easy ways to pay attention to the math and numbers that are all around us. The important thing is to use math as consciously as you use language so it becomes a regular, familiar part of your child’s day. ✨

A simple way to introduce math and numbers into your toddler’s day is by counting everything -- from toys, to fruit, even the steps from the car to your front door!

Counting helps familiarize your toddler with the concept that there are number words that go along with quantities. “I’m giving you four little crackers—one, two, three, four.” 🔢

Your toddler might start to do their own “counting” around two years old by reciting number words in order and pointing to objects in an attempt to mimic what you do when you count.

They are not yet making the connection between an actual quantity and the corresponding number word they are saying. Later, around age three or four, they will better understand what’s known as “one-to-one correspondence”—one ball goes with the number one, and two balls can be counted “one, two.”

We love this video from @Iniyaslearningjourney showing Iniya counting our Felt Flowers, a great example of a toddler reciting numbers and beginning to correspond them correctly. 🙌

#math #teachingmath #learningmath #toddlermath #learningnumbers #toddlerdevelopment #toddlerlearning #toddlerlife
